bcl:subrule.bcl:text: In these Supreme Court Civil Rules, unless the context otherwise requires:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: accessible address means an address that describes a unique and identifiable location in British Columbia that is accessible to the public during normal business hours for the delivery of documents;
action means a proceeding started by a notice of civil claim;
address for service, in relation to a party to a proceeding, means an address that is, under Rule 4-1, the party's address for service in the proceeding;
business day means a day on which the court registries are open for business;
case plan order means an order referred to in Rule 5-3 (3);
Chief Justice means the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of British Columbia;
court means the Supreme Court of British Columbia and, if a master has jurisdiction, includes a master of the Supreme Court;

document has an extended meaning and includes a photograph, video, recording of sound, any record of a permanent or semi-permanent character and any information recorded or stored by means of any device;
family law case has the same meaning as in the Supreme Court Family Rules;
fast track action means an action that is, under Rule 15-1 (1), an action to which Rule 15-1 applies;
file means file in the registry;
former Supreme Court Rules means the Supreme Court Rules, B.C. Reg. 221/90;
insurer means an insurer, as defined in the Financial Institutions Act, that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: has provided a policy of insurance to a party to an action in relation to matters or property in issue in that action, and
under that policy, is obligated to indemnify the party for liability imposed on the party in the action,

bcl:definition.bcl:text: and includes a surety of a party to an action in circumstances in which a claim has been made on a surety bond related to the matters in issue in the action;
order includes a judgment and a decree;
originating pleading means a notice of civil claim, counterclaim, third party notice or any document, other than a petition, that starts a proceeding;
party, in relation to a proceeding, means a person named as a party in the style of proceeding;
party of record, in relation to a proceeding, means a person who has filed a pleading, petition or response to petition in the proceeding, and includes,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in a proceeding referred to in Part 18, a person who has filed a notice of interest under that Part;
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 44/2014, Sch. 2, s. 1.]

bcl:definition.bcl:text: party's lawyer, in relation to a party to a proceeding, means the lawyer representing the party in that proceeding;
petition proceeding means a proceeding started by a petition;
plaintiff means a person who starts an action;
pleading means a notice of civil claim, a response to civil claim, a reply, a counterclaim, a response to counterclaim, a third party notice or a response to third party notice;
pleading period, in relation to an action, means the period for filing a responding pleading to the pleading that was most recently filed in the action;
proceeding means an action, a petition proceeding and a requisition proceeding, and includes any other suit, cause, matter, stated case under Rule 18-2 or appeal;
receiver includes receiver-manager;
registrar includes a district registrar and a deputy district registrar;
registrar's hearing means an inquiry, an assessment, an accounting, a review of a bill, an examination of an agreement or an assessment of a bill of costs;
registry, in relation to a proceeding, means the office of the court in which the proceeding is being conducted;
relief includes remedy;
requisition proceeding means a proceeding started by a requisition;
responding pleading means a response to civil claim, a response to counterclaim, a response to third party notice, a reply or any other document filed in response to an originating pleading;
serve, in relation to a document, means

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: serve by ordinary service in accordance with Rule 4-2 (2), or
if the document is one referred to in Rule 4-3 (1), serve by personal service in accordance with Rule 4-3 (2);

bcl:definition.bcl:text: special referee means any person, other than a master or registrar, who is appointed by the court under these Supreme Court Civil Rules or under an enactment to conduct an assessment, inquiry or accounting;
style of proceeding means, in relation to a document that is or is to be filed in a proceeding, that portion of the document that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: sets out the registry number attributed to the proceeding and the court and registry in which the proceeding is being or is to be conducted, and
identifies the parties to the proceeding or, if there is no person named as a defendant, the subject matter of the proceeding;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: third party means a person referred to in Rule 3-5 (1) against whom a third party claim is pursued;
witness list means a list setting out the name and address of each witness whom a party may call at trial;

writ of execution includes a writ of seizure and sale, a writ of sequestration, a writ of possession and a writ of delivery and any subsequent writ that issues to give effect to these writs, and also includes a warrant or other process of execution issued out of any court in British Columbia that has jurisdiction to grant and issue that process.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Interpretation Act and Supreme Court Act
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Unless a contrary intention appears, the Interpretation Act and the interpretation section of the Supreme Court Act apply to these Supreme Court Civil Rules.
The titles and headings of these Supreme Court Civil Rules are for convenience only and are not intended as a guide to interpretation.

Italicized words in square brackets are not part of these Supreme Court Civil Rules, are included editorially for convenience of reference only and are not to be used in interpreting the rules or any provision to which the words refer.
These Supreme Court Civil Rules may be cited as the "Supreme Court Civil Rules" and are included within any reference to the "Rules of Court" or the "Supreme Court Rules".
These Supreme Court Civil Rules govern every proceeding in the Supreme Court unless

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the proceeding is a family law case, in which case the Supreme Court Family Rules apply, or
an enactment otherwise provides.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: On application, and if all parties to a proceeding agree, the court may order that any provision of these Supreme Court Civil Rules does not apply to the proceeding.
If an enactment, other than these Supreme Court Civil Rules or the Supreme Court Family Rules, authorizes an application to the court or to a judge, the application must be

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by petition under Rule 16-1 or requisition under Rule 17-1, or
if the application is for an order other than a final order, by application under Part 8,

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: whether or not the enactment provides for the mode of application.
Subrule (4) does not apply if a particular mode of application is required by an enactment of Canada.
The object of these Supreme Court Civil Rules is to secure the just, speedy and inexpensive determination of every proceeding on its merits.
Securing the just, speedy and inexpensive determination of a proceeding on its merits includes, so far as is practicable, conducting the proceeding in ways that are proportionate to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the amount involved in the proceeding,
the importance of the issues in dispute, and
the complexity of the proceeding.

bcl:rule.bcl:text: Choosing the Correct Form of Proceeding

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Commencing proceedings by notice of civil claim
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Unless an enactment or these Supreme Court Civil Rules otherwise provide, every proceeding must be started by the filing of a notice of civil claim under Part 3.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Commencing proceedings by petition or requisition
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: To start a proceeding in the following circumstances, a person must file a petition or, if Rule 17-1 applies, a requisition:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the person starting the proceeding is the only person who is interested in the relief claimed, or there is no person against whom relief is sought;
the proceeding is brought in respect of an application that is authorized by an enactment to be made to the court;
the sole or principal question at issue is alleged to be one of construction of an enactment, will, deed, oral or written contract or other document;

the relief, advice or direction sought relates to a question arising in the execution of a trust, or the performance of an act by a person in the person's capacity as trustee, or the determination of the persons entitled as creditors or otherwise to the trust property;
the relief, advice or direction sought relates to the maintenance, guardianship or property of infants or other persons under disability;
the relief sought is for payment of funds into or out of court;
the relief sought relates to land and is for

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a declaration of a beneficial interest in or a charge on land and of the character and extent of the interest or charge,
a declaration that settles the priority between interests or charges,
an order that cancels a certificate of title or making a title subject to an interest or charge, or
an order of partition or sale;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the relief, advice or direction sought relates to the determination of a claim of solicitor and client privilege.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Without limiting any other provision of this Rule, a proceeding to which Part 25 applies may be started by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the filing of a submission for estate grant under Rule 25-3 (2),
the filing of a submission for resealing under Rule 25-6 (2),
the filing of a requisition under Rule 25-12 (2), 25-14 (1) or 25-14 (1.11), or
the filing of a petition under Rule 25-14 (1.1), (2) or (4).

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Without limiting subrules (1) to (2.1), the following provisions apply to the following applications and proceedings:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: Rule 8-3 applies to an application for an order by consent;
Rule 8-4 applies to an application of which notice need not be given;
Rule 10-3 applies to a proceeding brought to obtain relief by way of interpleader or in which such relief is sought;
Rule 14-1 (21) applies to an appointment for a review of a bill or an examination of an agreement under the Legal Profession Act;
Rule 15-1 applies to a fast track action;
Rule 18-2 applies to a stated case;
Rule 18-3 applies to an appeal that is authorized, by an enactment, to be made to the court;
Rule 19-3 applies to a proceeding to register a reciprocally enforceable judgment within the meaning of Rule 19-3;
Rule 21-1 applies to a proceeding brought in rem against a ship or other property;
Part 25 applies to a proceeding in relation to the administration of an estate;
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 149/2013, s. 1 (d).]
Rule 21-7 applies to a proceeding for foreclosure of the equitable right to redeem mortgaged property, for redemption or for cancellation of an agreement for sale.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: In this rule, tribunal award means any order, decision, judgment or other determination that, under an enactment, may be filed or registered in the court for enforcement purposes.
A tribunal award may be filed in a registry.
To file a tribunal award under subrule (2), a certified copy of the tribunal award must be attached to a requisition in Form 17.2 and the requisition must be filed.

bcl:part.bcl:text: Proceedings Started by Filing a Notice of Civil Claim

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: To start a proceeding under this Part, a person must file a notice of civil claim in Form 1.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Contents of notice of civil claim
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A notice of civil claim must do the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: set out a concise statement of the material facts giving rise to the claim;
set out the relief sought by the plaintiff against each named defendant;
set out a concise summary of the legal basis for the relief sought;
set out the proposed place of trial;
if the plaintiff sues or a defendant is sued in a representative capacity, show in what capacity the plaintiff sues or the defendant is sued;
provide the data collection information required in the appendix to the form;
otherwise comply with Rule 3-7.

bcl:rule.bcl:text: Serving and Renewing the Notice of Civil Claim

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Renewal of original notice of civil claim
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: An original notice of civil claim does not remain in force for more than 12 months, but if a defendant named in a notice of civil claim has not been served, the court, on the application of the plaintiff made before or after the expiration of the 12 months, may order that the original notice of civil claim be renewed for a period of not more than 12 months.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Further renewal of notice of civil claim
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a renewed notice of civil claim has not been served on a defendant named in the notice of civil claim, the court, on the application of the plaintiff made during the currency of the renewed notice of civil claim, may order the renewal of the notice of civil claim for a further period of not more than 12 months.
Unless the court otherwise orders, a renewal period ordered under subrule (1) or (2) begins on the date of the order.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: After renewal of notice of civil claim
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Unless the court otherwise orders, a copy of each order granting renewal of a notice of civil claim must be served with the renewed notice of civil claim, and the renewed notice of civil claim remains in force and is available to prevent the operation of any statutory limitation and for all other purposes.

bcl:rule.bcl:text: Responding to a Notice of Civil Claim

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Filing a response to civil claim
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: To respond to a notice of civil claim, a person must, within the time for response to civil claim referred to in subrule (3),

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: file a response to civil claim in Form 2, and
serve a copy of the filed response to civil claim on the plaintiff.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Contents of response to civil claim
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A response to civil claim under subrule (1)

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: indicate, for each fact set out in Part 1 of the notice of civil claim, whether that fact is

bcl:clause.bcl:text: outside the knowledge of the defendant,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: for any fact set out in Part 1 of the notice of civil claim that is denied, concisely set out the defendant's version of that fact, and
set out, in a concise statement, any additional material facts that the defendant believes relate to the matters raised by the notice of civil claim,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must indicate whether the defendant consents to, opposes or takes no position on the granting of the relief sought against that defendant in the notice of civil claim,
must, if the defendant opposes any of the relief referred to in paragraph (b) of this subrule, set out a concise summary of the legal basis for that opposition, and
must otherwise comply with Rule 3-7.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Period for filing response to civil claim
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Unless the court otherwise orders, to respond to a notice of civil claim, a response to civil claim under this rule must be filed and served within the following period:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of a notice of civil claim that is served on a person,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: if the person was served anywhere in Canada, within 21 days after that service,
if the person was served anywhere in the United States of America, within 35 days after that service, or
if the person was served anywhere else, within 49 days after that service;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of a notice of civil claim that is served on a ship or property under Rule 21-1 (5), within 21 days after service.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Payment into court when tender pleaded
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the response to civil claim alleges a defence of tender or tender of money by way of amends, the defendant must pay into court the amount alleged to have been tendered, failing which the defence of tender or tender of money by way of amends may be struck out.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Costs if defence of tender successful
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If, on a judgment, costs are awarded to a defendant who has paid into court under this rule, the assessed costs must be paid to the defendant out of the money in court.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Application for money paid into court
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A plaintiff may, before trial, apply to take out money paid into court under this rule, and the court may deal with costs of the action as if the defence of tender had succeeded.

If in an action for defamation the defendant is permitted to allege the plaintiff failed to mitigate his or her damages, the defendant may also allege tender of money by way of amends, whether the tender was made before or after action was started.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Consequence if fact not responded to
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: An allegation of fact in a notice of civil claim, if not admitted, denied or stated to be outside the knowledge of the defendant, is deemed to be outside the knowledge of the defendant.

A defendant in an action who wishes to pursue a claim within that action against the plaintiff must, within the time set out for the filing of a response to civil claim under Rule 3-3 (3), file a counterclaim in Form 3 that accords with Rule 3-7.

If the counterclaim referred to in subrule (1) raises questions between the defendant bringing the counterclaim and a person other than the plaintiff, the defendant may join that other person as a party against whom the counterclaim is brought.
In a counterclaim,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the plaintiff against whom the counterclaim is brought must be identified as the "plaintiff",
each defendant against whom the counterclaim is brought must, along with the defendant bringing the counterclaim, be identified as a "defendant", and
any other person against whom the counterclaim is brought must be identified as a "defendant by way of counterclaim".

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Unless the court otherwise orders, a defendant who files a counterclaim

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must serve a copy of the filed counterclaim on all parties of record within the time set out in Rule 3-3 (3) for the filing and service of a response to civil claim, and
if the counterclaim is brought against a person who is not yet a party of record to the action, must serve that defendant by way of counterclaim by personal service with

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a copy of the filed counterclaim, and
a copy of the filed notice of civil claim

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: within 60 days after the date on which the counterclaim was filed.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A person against whom a counterclaim is brought must, if that person wishes to dispute the counterclaim,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: file a response to counterclaim in Form 4 that accords with Rule 3-7, and
serve a copy of that filed response to counterclaim on all parties of record.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Except to the extent that this rule otherwise provides, Rules 3-1, 3-3 and 3-8 apply to a counterclaim as if it were a notice of civil claim and to a response to counterclaim as if it were a response to civil claim.
Without limiting subrule (6) of this rule, a defendant's counterclaim in an action may proceed even though the plaintiff's claim in the action has been stayed, discontinued or dismissed.

If, on the application of a party against whom a counterclaim is made, it appears that the subject matter of the counterclaim ought to be dealt with separately, the court may order that the counterclaim be struck out or tried separately or may make any other order the court considers will further the object of these Supreme Court Civil Rules.

If a set-off or counterclaim of a defendant establishes a defence to the plaintiff's claim, the court may grant judgment in favour of the defendant for any balance in the defendant's favour or for other relief as the court considers appropriate.
A party against whom relief is sought in an action may, if that party is not a plaintiff in the action, pursue a third party claim against any person if the party alleges that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the party is entitled to contribution or indemnity from the person in relation to any relief that is being sought against the party in the action,
the party is entitled to relief against the person and that relief relates to or is connected with the subject matter of the action, or
a question or issue between the party and the person

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: is substantially the same as a question or issue that relates to or is connected with

bcl:clause.bcl:text: relief claimed in the action, or
the subject matter of the action, and

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: should properly be determined in the action.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Subrule (1) does not preclude a plaintiff from pursuing a third party claim in his or her capacity as a defendant to a counterclaim.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Third party need not be party to original action
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A third party claim may be pursued against a person, whether or not that person is a party to the action.
Subject to subrule (4), a party wishing to pursue a third party claim referred to in subrule (1) must file a third party notice in Form 5 that accords with Rule 3-7.
A party may file a third party notice

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: at any time with leave of the court, or
without leave of the court, within 42 days after the filing of the response.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Court may consider case plan order
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the court makes an order under subrule (4) (a) in an action in which a case plan order has been made, the court may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: consider if and to what extent the case plan order is appropriate given the third party notice, and
amend the case plan order, if necessary, for that purpose.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Notice of an application for leave under subrule (4) (a) must be served on

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the third party, and
all parties of record.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Unless the court otherwise orders, a party who files a third party notice must,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: within 60 days after the date on which the third party notice is filed, serve on the third party

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a copy of the filed third party notice, and
if the third party is not a party of record at the time of service, a copy of any filed pleading that has previously been served by any party to the action, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: promptly after the date on which the third party notice is filed, serve a copy of the filed third party notice on all parties of record.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Application to set aside third party notice
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: At any time, on application, the court may set aside a third party notice.
Subject to subrule (10), if a third party wishes to dispute the third party notice, the third party must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: file a response to third party notice in Form 6 that accords with Rule 3-7, and
serve a copy of the filed response to third party notice on all parties of record.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: When response to third party notice not required
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A third party who is a defendant in the action need not file or serve a response to third party notice and is deemed to deny the facts alleged in the third party notice and to rely on the facts pleaded in that party's response to civil claim if all of the following apply:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the third party notice contains no claim other than a claim for contribution or indemnity under the Negligence Act;
the third party has filed and served a response to civil claim to the plaintiff's notice of civil claim;
the third party intends, in defending against the third party notice, to rely on the facts set out in the third party's response to civil claim and on no other facts.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Except to the extent that this rule otherwise provides, Rules 3-1 and 3-3 apply to a third party notice as if it were a notice of civil claim and to a response to third party notice as if it were a response to civil claim.

A third party who has filed a response to third party notice may, within the period for filing and serving a response to the third party notice, file and serve on all parties of record a response to civil claim to the plaintiff's notice of civil claim, raising any defence open to a defendant.
A party affected by a third party procedure may apply to the court for directions.
The court may impose terms on any third party procedure to limit or avoid any prejudice or unnecessary delay that might otherwise be suffered by a party as a result of that third party procedure.
An issue between the party filing the third party notice and the third party may be tried at the time the court may direct.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Default of response to third party notice
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a third party has not filed a response to third party notice and the time for filing the response to third party notice has expired, the party who filed the third party notice may apply for judgment in default of response to third party notice against the third party and notice of the application must be served on each other party of record.
On an application under subrule (16), the court may grant any or all of the relief claimed in the third party notice.
A plaintiff may, within 7 days after the response to civil claim has been served, file and serve on all parties of record a reply in Form 7 that accords with Rule 3-7.
No pleading subsequent to a reply may be filed or served without leave of the court.
If no reply to a response to civil claim is served, a joinder of issue on that response to civil claim is implied.
A reply that is a simple joinder of issue must not be filed or served.
A pleading must not contain the evidence by which the facts alleged in it are to be proved.

The effect of any document or the purport of any conversation referred to in a pleading, if material, must be stated briefly and the precise words of the documents or conversation must not be stated, except insofar as those words are themselves material.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: When presumed facts need not be pleaded
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A party need not plead a fact if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the fact is presumed by law to be true, or
the burden of disproving the fact lies on the other party.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: When performance of a condition precedent need not be pleaded
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A party need not plead the performance of a condition precedent necessary for the party's case unless the other party has specifically denied it in the other party's pleadings.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Matters arising since start of proceeding
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A party may plead a matter that has arisen since the start of the proceeding.
A party must not plead an allegation of fact or a new ground or claim inconsistent with the party's previous pleading.
Subrule (6) does not affect the right of a party to make allegations in the alternative or to amend or apply for leave to amend a pleading.
A party may raise in a pleading an objection in point of law.
Conclusions of law must not be pleaded unless the material facts supporting them are pleaded.
Unless the incorporation of a corporate party or the office or status of a party is specifically denied, it is deemed to be admitted.

A defendant in an action may set off or set up by way of counterclaim any right or claim, whether the set-off or counterclaim is for damages or not, so as to enable the court to pronounce a final judgment on all claims in the same action.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Pleading after the notice of civil claim
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: In a pleading subsequent to a notice of civil claim, a party must plead specifically any matter of fact or point of law that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the party alleges makes a claim or defence of the opposite party not maintainable,
if not specifically pleaded, might take the other party by surprise, or
raises issues of fact not arising out of the preceding pleading.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A pleading need not ask for general or other relief.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: General damages must not be pleaded
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If general damages are claimed, the amount of the general damages claimed must not be stated in any pleading.
If a party in a pleading denies an allegation of fact in the previous pleading of the opposite party, the party must not do so evasively but must answer the point of substance.

If a contract, promise or agreement is alleged in a pleading, a bare denial of it by the opposite party is to be construed only as a denial of fact of the express contract, promise or agreement alleged, or of the matters of fact from which it may be implied by law, and not as a denial of the legality or sufficiency in law of that contract, promise or agreement.
It is sufficient to allege malice, fraudulent intention, knowledge or other condition of the mind of a person as a fact, without setting out the circumstances from which it is to be inferred.

If the party pleading relies on misrepresentation, fraud, breach of trust, wilful default or undue influence, or if particulars may be necessary, full particulars, with dates and items if applicable, must be stated in the pleading.

If the particulars required under subrule (18) of debt, expenses or damages are lengthy, the party pleading may refer to this fact and, instead of pleading the particulars, must serve the particulars in a separate document either before or with the pleading.
Particulars need only be pleaded to the extent that they are known at the date of pleading, but further particulars

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: may be served after they become known, and
must be served within 10 days after a demand is made in writing.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: In an action for libel or slander,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the plaintiff alleges that the words or matter complained of were used in a derogatory sense other than their ordinary meaning, the plaintiff must give particulars of the facts and matters on which the plaintiff relies in support of that sense, and

if the defendant alleges that, insofar as the words complained of consist of statements of fact, they are true in substance and in fact, and that insofar as they consist of expressions of opinion, they are fair comment on a matter of public interest, the defendant must give particulars stating which of the words complained of the defendant alleges are statements of fact and of the facts and matters relied on in support of the allegation that the words are true.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The court may order a party to serve further and better particulars of a matter stated in a pleading.
Before applying to the court for particulars, a party must demand them in writing from the other party.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Demand for particulars not a stay of proceedings
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A demand for particulars does not operate as a stay of proceedings or give an extension of time, but a party may apply for an extension of time for serving a responding pleading on the ground that the party cannot answer the originating pleading until particulars are provided.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Default in filing and serving a response to civil claim
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A plaintiff may proceed against a defendant under this rule if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that defendant has not filed and served a response to civil claim, and
the period for filing and serving the response to civil claim has expired.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A plaintiff who wishes to proceed against a defendant under this rule must file

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: proof of service of the notice of civil claim on that defendant,
proof that the defendant has failed to serve a response to civil claim,
a requisition endorsed by a registrar with a notation that no response to civil claim has been filed by that defendant, and
a draft default judgment order in Form 8.

bcl:centertext.in:strong: Claims for Which Default Judgment Is Available

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Claim for specified or ascertainable amount
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the plaintiff's action against a defendant includes a claim for recovery of money in a specified or ascertainable amount, the plaintiff may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: on that claim, obtain judgment in Form 8 against that defendant for an amount not exceeding the total of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the amount claimed,
the interest, if any, to which the plaintiff is entitled, and
costs, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: proceed against one or more of the defendants, including the defendant against whom judgment was obtained, on any other claims brought in the action that are not barred as a result of the judgment referred to in paragraph (a).

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: For the purpose of subrule (3), a claim may be treated as a claim for recovery of money in a specified or ascertainable amount even though

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: part of the claim is for interest accruing after the date of the notice of civil claim, and
the interest is to be computed from the date of the notice of civil claim to the date that judgment is granted.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Claim for damages to be assessed
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the plaintiff's action against a defendant includes a claim for damages in an amount that is neither specified nor ascertainable, the plaintiff may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: on that claim, obtain judgment in Form 8 against that defendant for damages to be assessed and costs, and

proceed against one or more of the defendants, including the defendant against whom judgment was obtained, on any other claims brought in the action that are not barred as a result of the judgment referred to in paragraph (a).

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the plaintiff's action against a defendant includes a claim for the detention of goods, the plaintiff may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: on that claim, obtain

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: judgment in Form 8 against that defendant for the delivery of the goods, or their value to be assessed and costs, or
judgment in Form 8 against that defendant for the value of the goods to be assessed and costs, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: proceed against one or more of the defendants, including the defendant against whom judgment was obtained, on any other claims brought in the action that are not barred as a result of the judgment referred to in paragraph (a).

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 95/2011, Sch. A, s. 2 (a).]

If a registrar is not certain that a plaintiff's claim against a defendant relates to a claim within subrule (3), (5) or (6), the registrar may refuse to grant judgment and the plaintiff may apply to a judge or master for default judgment.
If the plaintiff's claim against a defendant is not one referred to in subrule (3), (5) or (6), the plaintiff may apply for judgment against the defendant under subrule (10).
The following apply to an application under subrule (9):

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the application may be brought under Rule 8-4;

the application must be supported by an affidavit setting out the facts that verify the claim and stating that the person swearing the affidavit knows of no fact that would constitute a defence to the claim except as to amount;
if the action in which the application is made is brought against several defendants, the court may

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: impose terms on any judgment for the plaintiff, including a stay of execution of the judgment until the trial of the action against the other defendants, or
adjourn the application until the trial of the action against the other defendants.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Court may set aside or vary default judgment
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The court may set aside or vary any judgment granted under this rule.
Subject to subrule (13), if a plaintiff has obtained judgment for damages to be assessed or value to be assessed,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the plaintiff may set the assessment down for trial, and
if the assessment is set for trial, unless the court otherwise orders, the assessment must be tried at the same time as the trial of the action or issues against any other defendant.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a plaintiff has obtained judgment under subrule (5) or (6), the plaintiff may, instead of proceeding to trial to assess the damages or the value of the goods, apply to the court, and, on that application, the court may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: assess the damages or value of the goods summarily on affidavit or other evidence,
order an assessment, an inquiry or an accounting,
give directions as to the trial or hearing of the assessment or determination of value, or
make any other order the court considers will further the object of these Supreme Court Civil Rules.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Required addresses for service of party represented by lawyer
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A party of record to a proceeding who is represented by a lawyer must have, as the party's addresses for service, both

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an e-mail address, if available, and
an accessible address that is an office address of that lawyer.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Required addresses for service of unrepresented party
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A party of record to a proceeding who is not represented by a lawyer must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: have, as the party's addresses for service, both

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: an e-mail address, if available, and
an accessible address within 30 kilometres of the registry, or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the party does not have an accessible address within 30 kilometres of the registry, have, as the party's addresses for service, both

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: an e-mail address, if available, and
either

bcl:clause.bcl:text: a postal address in British Columbia, or

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A party may have, in addition to the address or addresses for service the party is required to have under subrule (1) or (1.1), one or more of the following as addresses for service:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a postal address;
a fax number;
an additional e-mail address.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A party of record may change the party's address or addresses for service by filing and serving on the other parties of record a notice of address for service in Form 9 that shows, for the party,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the address or addresses for service required under subrule (1) or (1.1), and
any additional addresses for service referred to in subrule (2) that the party wishes to include.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Documents normally to be served by ordinary service
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Subject to Rule 4-3 (1) and unless the court otherwise orders, documents to be served by a party under these Supreme Court Civil Rules may be served by ordinary service.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How to serve documents by ordinary service
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Unless the court otherwise orders, ordinary service of a document is to be effected in any of the following ways on a person who has provided an address for service in the proceeding:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by leaving the document at the person's address for service;
by mailing the document by ordinary mail to the person's address for service;
subject to subrule (5) of this rule, if a fax number is provided as one of the person's addresses for service, by faxing the document to that fax number together with a fax cover sheet;
if an e-mail address is provided as one of the person's addresses for service, by e-mailing the document to that e-mail address.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: When service by delivery is deemed to be completed
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A document served by leaving it at a person's address for service is deemed to be served on the person as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the document is left at the address for service at or before 4 p.m. on a day that is not a Saturday or holiday, the document is deemed to be served on the day of service;
if the document is left at the address for service on a Saturday or holiday or after 4 p.m. on any other day, the document is deemed to be served on the next day that is not a Saturday or holiday.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: When service by mail is deemed to be completed
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A document sent for service by ordinary mail under this rule is deemed to be served one week later on the same day of the week as the day of mailing or, if that deemed day of service is a Saturday or holiday, on the next day that is not a Saturday or holiday.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: When documents may be served by fax
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A document may be served by fax as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the document, including the fax cover sheet, is less than 30 pages, the document may be served by fax at any time;
if the document, including the fax cover sheet, is 30 pages or more, the document may be served by fax if it is transmitted

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: between 5 p.m. and the following 8 a.m., or
at another time if the person receiving the document agreed to that time before service.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: When service by fax or e-mail is deemed to be completed
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A document transmitted for service by fax or e-mail under this rule is deemed to be served as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the document is transmitted before 4 p.m. on a day that is not a Saturday or holiday, the document is deemed to be served on the day of transmission;
if the document is transmitted on a Saturday or holiday or after 4 p.m. on any other day, the document is deemed to be served on the next day that is not a Saturday or holiday.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If no address for service given
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If, despite these Supreme Court Civil Rules, a party of record on whom a document is to be served has no address for service, and if these Supreme Court Civil Rules do not specify that the document must be served by personal service on the party,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the document may be served by mailing a copy of the document by ordinary mail to

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the party's lawyer, or
if the party has no lawyer representing the party in the proceeding, to the party's last known address, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: subrule (4) applies.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Request for copy of document served by e-mail
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a document is transmitted for service by e-mail and the person receiving the document requests, within 3 days of receiving that document, that a copy be sent to another address for service for that person, the party who served the document by e-mail must provide the copy at the requested address for service within 7 days of receiving that request or as agreed upon by the parties.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: When documents must be served by personal service
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Unless the court otherwise orders or these Supreme Court Civil Rules otherwise provide, the following documents must be served by personal service in accordance with subrule (2):

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a notice of civil claim;
a petition;
a counterclaim if that counterclaim is being served on a person who is not a party of record;
a third party notice if that third party notice is being served on a person who is not a party of record;
a subpoena to a witness who is not a party of record;
a subpoena to a debtor under Rule 13-3;
a subpoena under Rule 25-12;
a citation referred to in Rule 25-11;
a notice of intention to withdraw under Rule 22-6 if that notice is being served on the person who was being represented by the lawyer who filed the notice;
a notice of application under Rule 22-8 for an order for contempt;

any document not mentioned in paragraphs (a) to (i) of this subrule that is to be served on a person who is not a party of record to the proceeding or who has not provided an address for service in the proceeding under Rule 8-1 (11);
any other document that under these Supreme Court Civil Rules is to be served by personal service.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How to serve documents by personal service
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Unless the court otherwise orders, personal service of a document is to be effected as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: on an individual, by leaving a copy of the document with him or her;
on a corporation,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: by leaving a copy of the document with the president, chair, mayor or other chief officer of the corporation,
by leaving a copy of the document with the city clerk or municipal clerk,

by leaving a copy of the document with the manager, cashier, superintendent, treasurer, secretary, clerk or agent of the corporation or of any branch or agency of the corporation in British Columbia, or
in the manner provided by the Business Corporations Act or any enactment relating to the service of court documents,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: and, for the purpose of this paragraph, if the chief place of business of the corporation is outside British Columbia, every person who, within British Columbia, transacts or carries on any of the business of, or any business for, that corporation is deemed to be an agent of the corporation;
on an unincorporated association, other than a trade union, by leaving a copy of the document with any officer of the association;
on a trade union, by leaving a copy of the document with any officer of the trade union or with a business agent;
on an infant, in the manner provided by the Infants Act;
on a mentally incompetent person, by leaving a copy of the document

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: with the person's committee or, if there is no committee, with the person with whom the mentally incompetent person resides or in whose care he or she is or with the person appointed by the court to be served in the mentally incompetent person's place, and
with the Public Guardian and Trustee,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: and in no case is it necessary to show the original document;
on a principal referred to in subrule (3), in accordance with subrules (3) to (5);
on the Attorney General, in accordance with subrule (6).

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If an agent residing or carrying on business in British Columbia enters into a contract, in British Columbia, on behalf of a principal who resides outside British Columbia, and a proceeding is brought that relates to or arises out of that contract, a pleading or other document in that proceeding may be served on the agent with leave of the court.
The court may make an order granting leave under subrule (3) before the agent's authority or the agent's business relations with the principal have been determined.

Promptly after a pleading or other document is served on an agent under subrule (3), the party serving the pleading or other document must send, by registered mail to the principal at the principal's address outside British Columbia,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a copy of the entered order giving leave for that service, and
a copy of the filed pleading or other document.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A document to be served on the Attorney General must be served at the Ministry of Attorney General in the City of Victoria, and is sufficiently served if it is left during office hours with any lawyer on the staff of the Attorney General at Victoria or mailed by registered mail to the Deputy Attorney General at Victoria.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: When personal service is deemed to be completed
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A document served by personal service is deemed to be served as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the document is served at or before 4 p.m. on a day that is not a Saturday or holiday, the document is deemed to be served on the day of service;
if the document is served on a Saturday or holiday or after 4 p.m. on any other day, the document is deemed to be served on the next day that is not a Saturday or holiday.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If an originating pleading or petition has not been served on a person, but the person files a responding pleading or response to petition or attends at the trial or at the hearing of the petition, the originating pleading or petition is deemed to have been served on that person on the date the person files or attends.
If it is impracticable to serve a document by personal service or if the person to be served by personal service

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: cannot be found after a diligent search, or
is evading service of the documents,

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: the court may, on application without notice, make an order for substituted service granting permission to use an alternative method of service.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If an alternative service method is permitted
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a document is to be served by an alternative method permitted under subrule (1), a copy of the entered substituted service order that granted permission to use that alternative method must be served with the document unless

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the court otherwise orders, or
the alternative method of service permitted under subrule (1) is service by advertisement.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If, under subrule (1), the court permits a document to be served by advertisement, the advertisement must be in Form 10.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Service outside British Columbia without leave
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: An originating pleading, petition or other document may be served on a person outside British Columbia without leave in any of the circumstances enumerated in section 10 of the Court Jurisdiction and Proceedings Transfer Act.

A copy of an originating pleading or petition served outside British Columbia without leave must state, by endorsement in Form 11, the circumstances enumerated in section 10 of the Court Jurisdiction and Proceedings Transfer Act on which it is claimed that service is permitted under this rule.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Application for leave to serve outside the jurisdiction
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: In any case not provided for in subrule (1), leave of the court must be obtained before an originating pleading, petition or other document may be served outside British Columbia, and the court may grant such leave on an application referred to in subrule (4).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Applications may be made without notice
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: An application for leave to serve a person outside British Columbia

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: may be made without notice in accordance with Rule 8-1 (2) (b), and
must be supported by an affidavit or other evidence showing

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: in what place or country that person is or probably may be found, and
the grounds on which the application is made.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Service of order and related documents
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If an order is made granting leave to serve an originating pleading, petition or other document outside British Columbia, the following documents must be served with that originating pleading, petition or other document:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a copy of the filed notice of application or requisition for leave to serve;
a copy of all filed affidavits in support of the application;
a copy of the entered order granting leave to serve.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: This rule does not invalidate service of a document outside British Columbia without leave of the court if the document could have been validly served apart from this rule.
Despite this rule, the parties to a contract may agree

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that the court will have jurisdiction to hear a proceeding in respect of the contract, and
that a document in the proceeding may be served

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: at any place, within or outside British Columbia,
on any party,
on any person on behalf of any party, or
in any manner

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: specified or indicated in the contract.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Contract does not invalidate effective service
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Service of a document in accordance with a contract referred to in subrule (7) is effective service, but no contractual stipulation as to service of a document invalidates service that would otherwise be effective under these Supreme Court Civil Rules.
In subrules (10) to (13), Convention means the Convention on the Service Abroad of Judicial and Extrajudicial Documents in Civil or Commercial Matters, signed at the Hague on November 15, 1965.
A document may be served outside British Columbia

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in a manner provided by these Supreme Court Civil Rules for service in British Columbia,
in a manner provided by the law of the place where service is made if, by that manner of service, the document could reasonably be expected to come to the notice of the person to be served, or
in a state that is a contracting state under the Convention, in a manner provided by or permitted under the Convention.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Service of a document outside British Columbia may be proved

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in a manner provided by these Supreme Court Civil Rules for proof of service in British Columbia,
in the manner provided for proof of service by the law of the place where service was made regardless of the manner under subrule (10) by which service was effected, or
in accordance with the Convention, if service was effected under subrule (10) (c).

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If service is to be made in accordance with Article 5 of the Convention, Forms 12 and 13 must be used.
If an authority has, in accordance with Article 6 of the Convention, completed a certificate in Form 14, the certificate is evidence of the facts stated in it.
Service of a document is proved as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: service on a person of an originating pleading is proved

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: by filing an affidavit of personal service in Form 15, or
by the person filing a responding pleading;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: service on a person of a petition is proved

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: by filing an affidavit of personal service in Form 15, or
by the person filing a response to petition;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: service of any other document served by personal service is proved by filing an affidavit of personal service in Form 15;
service of any document that is served by ordinary service is proved

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: by filing an affidavit of ordinary service in Form 16, or
by filing a requisition in Form 17 to which is attached a written acknowledgment of receipt signed by the party or lawyer on whom the document was served.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Service of a document by a sheriff may be proved by a certificate in Form 18 endorsed on a copy of the document.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Service on member of Canadian Armed Forces
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a member of the Canadian Armed Forces has been served with a document by an officer of the Canadian Armed Forces, proof of the service in the form of a certificate annexed to a copy of the document served, signed by the officer and stating his or her rank and when, where and how service was effected, may be filed as proof of service.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Admissibility of other evidence of service
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Nothing in subrules (1) to (3) restricts the court from considering any other evidence of service that the court considers appropriate in the circumstances.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If service is alleged to be ineffective
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a document has been served in accordance with this Part but a person can show that the document

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: did not come to his or her notice,
came to his or her notice later than when it was served, or
was incomplete or illegible,

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: the court may set aside an order, extend time, order an adjournment or make such other order as it considers will further the object of these Supreme Court Civil Rules.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Case planning conference may be requested
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A party of record to an action may, at any time after the pleading period has expired, request a case planning conference by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: obtaining a date and time for the case planning conference from the registry, and
filing a notice of case planning conference in Form 19.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Case planning conference may be directed
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Without limiting subrule (1), at any stage of an action after the pleading period has expired, the court

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: may direct that a case planning conference take place, and
in that case, must direct that a party request a case planning conference in accordance with subrule (1).

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Unless the court otherwise orders or the parties of record otherwise agree, a party who is requesting a case planning conference under subrule (1) or who has been directed to file a notice of case planning conference under subrule (2) must serve the filed notice of case planning conference on the other parties of record,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of the first case planning conference to be held in the action, at least 35 days, or any shorter period that the court may order, before the date set for the case planning conference, and
in the case of any other case planning conference to be held in the action, at least 7 days, or any shorter period that the court may order, before the date set for the case planning conference.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Application must be made by requisition
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: An application under subrule (3) (a) or (b) to shorten the service period applicable to a notice of case planning conference

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must be made by requisition in Form 19.1, and
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 176/2023, Sch. 1, s. 6 (b).]
unless the court otherwise orders, may be made without notice.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Unless the court otherwise orders, if a case planning conference is requested or ordered under this rule, the parties of record must, before the first case planning conference to be held in the action, file case plan proposals as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the party of record who is requesting the case planning conference must, within 14 days after serving the notice of case planning conference,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: file the party's case plan proposal, and
serve a copy of the filed case plan proposal on all other parties of record;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: each other party of record must, within 14 days after receipt of the case plan proposal referred to in paragraph (a),

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: file the party's case plan proposal, and
serve a copy of the filed case plan proposal on all other parties of record.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A party's case plan proposal referred to in subrule (5) must be in Form 20 and must, in a summary manner, indicate the party's proposal with respect to the following steps:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: discovery of documents;
examinations for discovery;
dispute resolution procedures;
expert witnesses;
witness lists;
trial type, estimated trial length and preferred periods for the trial date.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Case planning conference must be conducted by judge or master
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A case planning conference held in an action must be conducted by a judge or master.
Unless the court otherwise orders, the following persons must attend a case planning conference in accordance with subrule (3):

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: each lawyer representing a party of record;
a party of record if

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the party is not represented by a lawyer in the action, or
the party is ordered to attend by the court.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Unless the court otherwise orders, a lawyer or party of record referred to in subrule (2) must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: attend in person at the first case planning conference held in an action, and
attend any subsequent case planning conference held in the action

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: by telephone or other communication medium, if all persons participating in the case planning conference, whether by telephone, by other communication medium or in person, are able to communicate with each other, or
in person.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Application must be made by requisition
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Each application under subrule (2) for an order exempting a person from attending a case planning conference and an application under subrule (3) respecting the method of attendance

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must be made by requisition in Form 20.1, and
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 176/2023, Sch. 1, s. 7 (b).]
unless the court otherwise orders, may be made without notice.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If an application is brought under subrule (2) for an order exempting a person from attending a case planning conference, the court may make such an order if the court considers that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: it is not reasonably possible for the person to attend given the distance the person has to travel for that attendance or the cost required for that attendance,
attendance must be excused on health or compassionate grounds, or
other extraordinary circumstances exist that justify the order.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a person who, under subrule (2), is required to attend a case planning conference fails to attend at that case planning conference, the case planning conference judge or master may do one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: proceed in the absence of the person who failed to attend;
adjourn the case planning conference;
order that the person, or the party on whose behalf the person was to attend, pay costs to one or more other parties.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Proceedings at a case planning conference must be recorded, but no part of that recording may be made available to or used by any person without court order.
At a case planning conference, the case planning conference judge or master may make one or more of the following orders in respect of the action, whether or not on the application of a party:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: setting a timetable for the steps to be taken;
amending a previous case plan order;
any order referred to in Rule 22-4 (2);
requiring amendment of a pleading to provide details of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the facts,
the relief sought, or
the legal basis on which relief is sought or opposed

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: set out in that pleading;
respecting the length and content of pleadings;
respecting discovery, listing, production, preservation, exchange or examination of documents or exhibits, including, without limitation, orders

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: respecting electronically stored information, and
that discovery, listing, production, exchange or examination be limited or otherwise conducted as ordered;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: respecting discovery of parties or the examination or inspection of persons or property, including, without limitation, that discovery, examination or inspection be limited, expanded or otherwise conducted in the manner ordered;
respecting interrogatories;

respecting third party claims, including imposing terms on any third party procedure to limit or avoid any prejudice or unnecessary delay that might otherwise be suffered by the plaintiff as a result of that third party procedure;
respecting witness lists;
respecting experts, including, without limitation, orders

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: that the expert evidence on any one or more issues be given by one jointly-instructed expert,
respecting the number of experts a party may call,
that the parties' experts must confer before the service of their respective reports,
setting a date by which an expert's report must be served on the other parties of record, and
respecting the issues on which an expert may be called;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: respecting admissions;
respecting offers to settle;
respecting the conduct of any application, including, without limitation, that an application may be made by written submissions under Rule 8-6;

requiring the parties of record to attend one or more of a mediation, a settlement conference or any other dispute resolution process, and giving directions for the conduct of the mediation, settlement conference or other dispute resolution process;
authorizing or directing the parties of record to try one or more issues in the action independently of others;
fixing the length of trial;
respecting the place at which any step in the action is to be conducted;
setting the action for trial on a particular date or on a particular trial list;
striking out a counterclaim or directing that a counterclaim be tried separately;
adjourning the case planning conference;
directing the parties to attend a further case planning conference at a specified date and time;
any orders the judge or master considers will further the object of these Supreme Court Civil Rules.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A case planning conference judge or master must not, at a case planning conference,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: hear any application supported by affidavit evidence, except under subrule (6), or
make an order for final judgment, except by consent or under subrule (6).

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Without limiting subrules (1) and (2), the judge or master conducting a case planning conference must, at the conclusion of the case planning conference, make a case plan order.
A case plan order under subrule (3) must be in Form 21 and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must set out any order made under subrule (1), and
may but need not include any other matter referred to in Form 21.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: When approval in writing by lawyer not required
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Without limiting Rule 13-1 (2), if a case plan order under subrule (3) is approved in writing by the case planning conference judge or master, that order need not be approved in writing by a lawyer or by a party.

If a party fails to comply with this Part or an order made under this rule or if anything is done or omitted improperly or unnecessarily by or on behalf of a party in relation to anything under this Part, the court may, on application, do one or both of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: make an order under Rule 22-7;
despite any other provision of these Supreme Court Civil Rules to the contrary and without limiting Rule 14-1 (14),

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: award costs of the application in a lump sum fixed under Schedule 3 of Appendix B, and
set the period within which those costs must be paid.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Application may be made at case planning conference
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Without limiting Part 8, a party may apply for an order under subrule (6) at a case planning conference.

Without limiting the ability of a case planning conference judge or master to amend a case plan order at a case planning conference under Rule 5-3 (1) (b), the parties may apply to amend a case plan order as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the application is to be by consent, the parties must apply under Rule 8-1 (2) (a);
if the application is not to be by consent, a party of record must request a subsequent case planning conference under Rule 5-1.

bcl:part.bcl:text: Amendment of Pleadings and Change of Parties

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Subject to Rules 6-2 (7) and (10) and 7-7 (5), a party may amend the whole or any part of a pleading filed by the party, other than to change parties or withdraw an admission,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: once without leave of the court, at any time before service of the notice of trial, or
after the notice of trial is served, only with

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: leave of the court, or
written consent of the parties.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Unless the court otherwise orders, to amend a pleading under subrule (1), a party must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: amend the pleading in accordance with subrule (3),
indicate on the amended pleading the date on which the original version of the pleading was filed, and
file the amended pleading.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Unless the court otherwise orders, if a pleading is amended under this rule,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: any deleted wording must be shown as struck out, and
any new wording must be underlined.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Unless the court otherwise orders, if a party amends a pleading under this rule, the party must do both of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: within 7 days after filing the amended pleading, serve, by ordinary service, a copy of the filed amended pleading on all parties of record;

if the amended pleading is an originating pleading, promptly after filing the amended pleading and before taking any further step in the proceeding, serve, by personal service, a copy of the filed amended originating pleading on any person who

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: was served with a copy of the filed original version of the originating pleading, and
has not filed a responding pleading to the original version of the originating pleading.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Response of a party to amended document
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a pleading (in this subrule and in subrule (6) called the "primary pleading") is amended under this rule and the amended pleading is served on a party of record under subrule (4) (a), that party

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: may amend, under this rule, any pleading he or she had filed in response to the original version of the primary pleading but only with respect to any matter raised by the amendments to the primary pleading, and
in that event, must, within 14 days after being served with the amended pleading, serve a copy of the filed amended responding pleading on all parties of record.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Failure to serve amended responding document
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a party on whom an amended pleading is served under subrule (4) (a) does not serve an amended responding pleading as provided in subrule (5),

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the pleading he or she filed in response to the original version of the primary pleading is deemed to be the pleading he or she filed in response to the amended pleading, and
any new facts set out in the amended pleading are deemed to be outside the knowledge of the defendant.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If an originating pleading is amended under this rule and served under subrule (4) (b) on a person who is not yet a party of record, the person has the same period for filing a responding pleading to that amended originating pleading as the party had to file a responding pleading to the original version of the originating pleading.
Unless the court otherwise orders, if an amendment is granted during a trial or hearing, an order need not be taken out and the amended pleading need not be filed or served.

bcl:centertext.in:strong: Change of Party Status or Interest

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a party dies or becomes bankrupt, or a corporate party is wound up or otherwise ceases to exist, but the claim survives, the proceeding may continue in spite of the death or bankruptcy or the corporate party having been wound up or ceasing to exist.

Whether or not the claim survives, a proceeding may continue in spite of either party dying between the verdict or finding on the issues of fact and the entry of judgment, but judgment may be entered despite the death.

If, by assignment, conveyance or death, an estate, interest or title devolves or is transferred, a proceeding relating to that estate, interest or title may be continued by or against the person on whom that estate, interest or title has devolved or to whom that estate, interest or title has been transferred.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Change or transmission of interest or liability
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If, after the start of a proceeding,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a change or transmission of interest or liability of a party takes place or a person interested comes into existence, and
it becomes necessary or desirable that

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a person not already a party should be made a party, or
a person already a party should be made a party in another capacity,

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: the court may order that the proceeding be continued between the continuing parties and the new party.
bcl:subrule.bcl:hnote: [am. B.C. Reg. 119/2010, Sch. A, ss. 12 and 13.]

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Prosecution of proceeding if plaintiff or petitioner dies
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a plaintiff or petitioner has died and the proceeding may be continued, a defendant or respondent may apply to the court for an order that the person entitled to proceed do proceed within the time that the court orders and that, in default, the proceeding be dismissed for want of prosecution.
If a proceeding is dismissed under subrule (5), an order for payment of costs may be made and enforced against the assets of the deceased's estate.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Adding, removing or substituting parties by order
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: At any stage of a proceeding, the court, on application by any person, may, subject to subrules (9) and (10),

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: order that a person cease to be party if that person is not, or has ceased to be, a proper or necessary party,
order that a person be added or substituted as a party if

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: that person ought to have been joined as a party, or
that person's participation in the proceeding is necessary to ensure that all matters in the proceeding may be effectually adjudicated on, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: order that a person be added as a party if there may exist, between the person and any party to the proceeding, a question or issue relating to or connected with

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: any relief claimed in the proceeding, or
the subject matter of the proceeding

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: that, in the opinion of the court, it would be just and convenient to determine as between the person and that party.
bcl:subrule.bcl:hnote: [am. B.C. Reg. 119/2010, Sch. A, ss. 12 and 13.]

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Procedure if party added, removed or substituted by order
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Unless the court otherwise orders, if an order is made under subrule (7) adding, removing or substituting a party,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the originating pleading or petition must be amended in accordance with these Supreme Court Civil Rules, a reference to the order must be endorsed on that amended pleading or petition and Rule 6-1 (4) to (7) applies,

no further steps may be taken against a person added or substituted as a party under this subrule until a copy of the filed amended originating pleading or filed amended petition and a copy of the entered order adding or substituting the party are served on the person, and
if a person is made a party under the order,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the person may apply to the court to vary or discharge the order within 21 days after the date on which the order is served on the person under paragraph (b) of this subrule, and

unless the court orders, in an application under subparagraph (i) of this paragraph or otherwise, that the person not be added as a party, these Supreme Court Civil Rules apply in relation to that added party as if the amended originating pleading or petition were a new originating pleading or petition.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If case plan order in effect
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If an order is made under subrule (4) or (7) in an action in which a case plan order has been made,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if a person is removed as a party, the case plan order remains in effect, and

if a person is added or substituted as a party and that person becomes a party of record, no step may be taken by or against the added or substituted party until the case plan order is amended to apply to the added or substituted party.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Unless the court otherwise orders, an application under subrule (7) may be made without notice to any person who is not a party.
A person must not be added or substituted as a plaintiff or petitioner without the person's consent.

Unless the court otherwise orders, if a person becomes a party in substitution for a former party, all things done in the proceeding before the person became a party have the same effect in relation to that person as they had in relation to the former party, but the substituted party must file a notice of address for service in Form 9.
Unless all parties of record consent or the court otherwise orders, each party of record to an action must, within 35 days after the end of the pleading period,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: prepare a list of documents in Form 22 that lists

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: all documents that are or have been in the party's possession or control and that could, if available, be used by any party of record at trial to prove or disprove a material fact, and
all other documents to which the party intends to refer at trial, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: serve the list on all parties of record.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Subject to subrules (6) and (7), each party's list of documents must include a brief description of each listed document.
A party must include in the party's list of documents any insurance policy under which an insurer may be liable

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to satisfy the whole or any part of a judgment granted in the action, or
to indemnify or reimburse any party for any money paid by that party in satisfaction of the whole or any part of such a judgment.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Despite subrule (3), information concerning the insurance policy must not be disclosed to the court at trial unless it is relevant to an issue in the action.
For the purposes of subrules (3) and (4), insurance policy does not include an application for insurance.
If it is claimed that a document is privileged from production, the claim must be made in the list of documents with a statement of the grounds of the privilege.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Nature of privileged documents to be described
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The nature of any document for which privilege from production is claimed must be described in a manner that, without revealing information that is privileged, will enable other parties to assess the validity of the claim of privilege.
The court may order a party of record to serve an affidavit verifying a list of documents.
If, after a list of documents has been served under this rule,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: it comes to the attention of the party serving it that the list is inaccurate or incomplete, or

there comes into the party's possession or control a document that could be used by any party of record at trial to prove or disprove a material fact or any other document to which the party intends to refer at trial,

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: the party must promptly amend the list of documents and serve the amended list of documents on the other parties of record.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Party may demand documents required under this rule
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a party who has received a list of documents believes that the list omits documents or a class of documents that should have been disclosed under subrule (1) (a) or (9), the party may, by written demand, require the party who prepared the list to
