bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: amend the list of documents,
serve on the demanding party the amended list of documents, and
make the originals of the newly listed documents available for inspection and copying in accordance with subrules (15) and (16).

bcl:subrule.bcl:hnote: [am. B.C. Reg. 119/2010, Sch. A, s. 14 (b) and (c).]

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a party who has received a list of documents believes that the list should include documents or classes of documents that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: are within the listing party's possession, power or control,
relate to any or all matters in question in the action, and
are additional to the documents or classes of documents required under subrule (1) (a) or (9),

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: the party, by written demand that identifies the additional documents or classes of documents with reasonable specificity and that indicates the reason why such additional documents or classes of documents should be disclosed, may require the listing party to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: amend the list of documents,
serve on the demanding party the amended list of documents, and
make the originals of the newly listed documents available for inspection and copying in accordance with subrules (15) and (16).

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A party who receives a demand under subrule (10) or (11) must, within 35 days after receipt, do one of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: comply with the demand in relation to the demanded documents;
comply with the demand in relation to those of the demanded documents that the party is prepared to list and indicate, in relation to the balance of the demanded documents,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: why an amended list of documents that includes those documents is not being prepared and served, and
why those documents are not being made available;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: indicate, in relation to the demanded documents,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: why an amended list of documents that includes those documents is not being prepared and served, and
why those documents are not being made available.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a party who receives a demand under subrule (10) or (11) does not, within 35 days after receipt, comply with the demand in relation to the demanded documents, the demanding party may apply for an order requiring the listing party to comply with the demand.
On an application under subrule (13) or otherwise, the court may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: order that a party be excused from compliance with subrule (1), (3), (6), (15) or (16) or with a demand under subrule (10) or (11), either generally or in respect of one or more documents or classes of documents, or
order a party to

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: amend the list of documents to list additional documents that are or have been in the party's possession, power or control relating to any or all matters in question in the action,
serve the amended list of documents on all parties of record, and
make the originals of the newly listed documents available for inspection and copying in accordance with subrules (15) and (16).

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A party who has served a list of documents on any other party must allow the other party to inspect and copy, during normal business hours and at the location specified in the list of documents, the listed documents except those documents that the listing party objects to producing.

If a party is entitled to inspect listed documents under subrule (15), the listing party must, on the request of the party entitled to inspection and on receiving payment in advance of the cost of reproduction and service, serve on the requesting party copies of the documents, if reproducible, for which a request has been made.
The court may order the production of a document for inspection and copying by any party or by the court at a time and place and in the manner it considers appropriate.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Documents not in possession of party
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a document is in the possession or control of a person who is not a party of record, the court, on an application under Rule 8-1 brought on notice to the person and the parties of record, may make an order for one or both of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: production, inspection and copying of the document;
preparation of a certified copy that may be used instead of the original.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: An order under subrule (18) may be made by consent if that order is endorsed with an acknowledgment by the person in possession or control of the document that the person has no objection to the terms of the proposed order.

If, on an application for production of a document, production is objected to on the grounds of privilege, the court may inspect the document for the purpose of deciding the validity of the objection.

Unless the court otherwise orders, if a party fails to make discovery of or produce for inspection or copying a document as required by this rule, the party may not put the document in evidence in the proceeding or use it for the purpose of examination or cross-examination.

If the party from whom discovery, inspection or copying of a document is sought objects to that discovery, inspection or copying, the court may, if satisfied that for any reason it is desirable that an issue or question in dispute should be determined before deciding on the right to discovery, inspection or copying, order that the issue or question be determined first and reserve the question of discovery, inspection or copying.
Subject to subrule (2), each party of record to an action must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: make himself or herself available, or
if any of subrules (5) to (10) apply, make a person referred to in that subrule available,

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: for examinations for discovery by the parties of record to the action who are adverse in interest to the party subject to examination.

Unless the court otherwise orders, the examinations for discovery, including all examinations under subrules (17), (22) and (24), conducted under this rule of a party of record, including any such examinations conducted of a person referred to in subrule (1) (b) who is examined in relation to that party of record, by any other party of record who is adverse in interest must not, in total, exceed in duration

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: 7 hours, or
any greater period to which the person to be examined consents.

bcl:lefttext.in:em: [See Rule 15-1 (11) and (12) for limits on examinations for discovery in fast track actions.]

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: In an application under subrule (2) to extend the examination for discovery period, the court must consider the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the conduct of a person who has been or is to be examined, including

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the person's unresponsiveness in any examination for discovery held in the action,
the person's failure to provide complete answers to questions, or
the person's provision of answers that are evasive, irrelevant, unresponsive or unduly lengthy;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: any denial or refusal to admit, by a person who has been or is to be examined, anything that should have been admitted;
the conduct of the examining party;
whether or not it is or was reasonably practicable to complete the examinations for discovery within the period provided under subrule (2);
the number of parties and examinations for discovery and the proximity of the various interests of those parties.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: An examination for discovery is an oral examination on oath.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Examination of party that is not an individual
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Unless the court otherwise orders, if a party to be examined for discovery is not an individual,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the examining party may examine one representative of the party to be examined,
the party to be examined must nominate as its representative an individual, who is knowledgeable concerning the matters in question in the action, to be examined on behalf of that party, and
the examining party may examine

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the representative nominated under paragraph (b), or
any other person the examining party considers appropriate and who is or has been a director, officer, employee, agent or external auditor of the party to be examined.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Examination of person for whose benefit action brought
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Subject to subrule (9), a person for whose immediate benefit an action is brought or defended may be examined for discovery.
If an action is brought by an assignee, the assignor may be examined for discovery.
Unless the court otherwise orders, if a party to be examined for discovery is an infant, the infant, his or her guardian and his or her litigation guardian may be examined for discovery.

If a party to be examined for discovery is a mentally incompetent person, his or her litigation guardian and his or her committee may be examined for discovery, but the mentally incompetent person must not be examined without leave of the court.
If a party to be examined for discovery is a trustee in bankruptcy, the bankrupt may be examined for discovery.

Unless the court otherwise orders or the parties to the examination for discovery otherwise agree, an examination for discovery must take place at a location within 30 kilometres of the registry that is nearest to the place where the person to be examined resides.
An examination for discovery must be conducted before an official reporter who is empowered to administer the oath.
Before conducting an examination for discovery under this rule, the party wishing to conduct that examination for discovery must do the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the person to be examined is a party of record to, and has a lawyer in, the action, ensure that, at least 7 days before the examination for discovery,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: an appointment in Form 23 is served on that lawyer, and
witness fees in the amount required under Schedule 3 of Appendix C are tendered to that lawyer;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in any other case, ensure that, at least 7 days before the examination for discovery,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: an appointment in Form 23 is served on the person to be examined, and
witness fees in the amount required under Schedule 3 of Appendix C are tendered to the person to be examined;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: at least 7 days before the examination for discovery, serve a copy of the appointment on all parties of record.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A person to be examined for discovery must attend and submit to examination for discovery if the party wishing to conduct that examination for discovery has complied with subrule (13) (a) or (b), as the case may be.
If a lawyer receives witness fees under subrule (13) (a), those fees must not be attached.

Unless the court otherwise orders, if the person to be examined for discovery is a person referred to in subrule (6), (7), (8), (9) or (10), the person must produce for inspection on the examination for discovery all documents in his or her possession or control, not privileged, relating to the matters in question in the action.

The examination for discovery of a person is in the nature of a cross-examination, and the person examined for discovery may be re-examined on his or her own behalf or on behalf of a party of record not adverse in interest to him or her in relation to any matter respecting which he or she has been examined.
Unless the court otherwise orders, a person being examined for discovery

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must answer any question within his or her knowledge or means of knowledge regarding any matter, not privileged, relating to a matter in question in the action, and
is compellable to give the names and addresses of all persons who reasonably might be expected to have knowledge relating to any matter in question in the action.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Without limiting subrule (18), unless the court otherwise orders, a person being examined for discovery must answer any question within his or her knowledge or means of knowledge that is related to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the existence and contents of any insurance policy under which an insurer may be liable

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: to satisfy the whole or any part of a judgment granted in the action, or
to indemnify or reimburse a party for any money paid by that party in satisfaction of the whole or any part of such a judgment, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the amount of money available under the policy, and any communication from an insurer denying or limiting liability under the policy.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Despite subrule (19), information concerning the insurance policy must not be disclosed to the court at trial unless it is relevant to an issue in the action.
For the purposes of subrules (19) and (20), insurance policy does not include an application for insurance.
In order to comply with subrule (18) or (19), a person being examined for discovery may be required to inform himself or herself and the examination may be adjourned for that purpose.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Response may be provided by letter
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a person is required to inform himself or herself under subrule (22) in order to respond to one or more questions posed on the examination for discovery, the examining party may request the person to provide the responses by letter.
If the examining party receives a letter under subrule (23),

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the questions set out in the letter and the answers given in response to those questions are deemed for all purposes to be questions asked and answers given under oath in the examination for discovery, and
the examining party may, subject to subrule (2), continue the examination for discovery.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a person under examination objects to answering a question put to him or her, the question and the objection must be taken down by the official reporter and the court may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: decide the validity of the objection, and
order the person to submit to further examination and set a maximum duration for that further examination.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: An examination for discovery is to be taken down in the form of question and answer, and copies of the transcript may be obtained on payment of the proper fee by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: any party of record,
the person examined, or
any other person as the court for special reason may permit.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Application to persons outside British Columbia
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: So far as is practicable, this rule applies to a person residing outside British Columbia, and the court, on application on notice to the person, may order the examination for discovery of the person at a place and in the manner the court considers appropriate.
Unless the court otherwise orders, if an order is made under subrule (27) for the examination for discovery of a person,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the order and the notice of appointment may be served on, and
the witness fees referred to in subrule (13) may be paid to

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: the lawyer for the person.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Party may serve interrogatories by consent or with leave
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A party of record to an action may serve interrogatories in Form 24 on any other party of record, or on a director, officer, partner, agent, employee or external auditor of a party of record, if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the party of record to be examined consents, or
the court grants leave.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a party is a body of persons
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a party of record to an action is a body of persons, corporate or unincorporate, that is empowered to sue or to be sued in its own name or in the name of an officer or other person, another party of record may, with leave of the court granted at an application or if authorized to do so by a case plan order, serve interrogatories on the officer or member of the body specified in the order.
In an order granting leave under subrule (1) (b) or (2), the court may set terms and conditions on the interrogatories, including terms and conditions respecting

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the number or length of the interrogatories,
the matters the interrogatories are to cover,
the timing of any response to the interrogatories, and
the notification, if any, to be given to the other parties of record respecting the interrogatories.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A person to whom interrogatories are directed must, within 21 days or such other period as the court may order under subrule (3), serve an answer on affidavit to the interrogatories.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If more than one person to answer interrogatories
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If interrogatories are required to be answered by more than one officer, director, partner, agent or employee of a party, the interrogatories must state which of the interrogatories each person is required to answer.

If a person objects to answering an interrogatory on the grounds of privilege or on the grounds that it does not relate to a matter in question in the action, the person may make the objection in an affidavit in answer.
If a person to whom interrogatories have been directed answers any of them insufficiently, the court may require the person to make a further answer either by affidavit or on oral examination.
If a party of record objects to an interrogatory on the grounds that it will not further the object of these Supreme Court Civil Rules,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the party may apply to the court to strike out the interrogatory, and
the court must take into account any offer by the party to make admissions, to produce documents or to give oral discovery.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A party of record may, instead of serving interrogatories under subrule (1) or (2), serve the interrogatories on the lawyer of the person to whom the interrogatories are directed.
If a lawyer receives interrogatories under subrule (9), the lawyer must promptly inform the person to whom the interrogatories are directed.

If a person who has given an answer to an interrogatory later learns that the answer is inaccurate or incomplete, the person must promptly serve on the party who served the interrogatory an affidavit deposing to an accurate or complete answer.
If a person who is not a party of record to an action may have material evidence relating to a matter in question in the action, the court may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: order that the person be examined on oath on the matters in question in the action, and
either before or after the examination, order that the examining party pay reasonable lawyer's costs of the person relating to the application and the examination.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: An expert retained or specially employed by another party in anticipation of litigation or preparation for trial may not be examined under this rule unless the party seeking the examination is unable to obtain facts and opinions on the same subject by other means.
An application for an order under subrule (1) must be supported by affidavit setting out

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the matter in question in the action to which the applicant believes that the evidence of the proposed witness may be material,

if the proposed witness is an expert retained or specially employed by another party in anticipation of litigation or preparation for trial, that the applicant is unable to obtain facts and opinions on the same subject by other means, and
that the proposed witness

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: has refused or neglected on request by the applicant to give a responsive statement, either orally or in writing, relating to the witness' knowledge of the matters in question, or
has given conflicting statements.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: An applicant for an order under subrule (1) must comply with Rule 8-1, and, without limiting this, the applicant must serve the application materials on the proposed witness and Rule 8-1 applies to the witness as if he or she were a party of record.

If the court makes an order under subrule (1) entitling a party to examine a person under this rule, the party may, by serving on the person to be examined a subpoena in Form 25, require the person to bring to the examination

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: any document in the person's possession or control relating to the matters in question in the action, and
any physical object in the person's possession or control that the party contemplates tendering at the trial as an exhibit.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A subpoena referred to in subrule (5)

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: need not identify any document referred to in subrule (5) (a), and
must identify any object referred to in subrule (5) (b).

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The examining party must give notice of an examination under this rule by serving copies of the subpoena referred to in subrule (5) on all parties of record at least 7 days before the date appointed for the examination.

The proposed witness must be cross-examined by the party who obtained the order, then may be cross-examined by any other party of record, and then may be further cross-examined by the party who obtained the order.
Unless the court otherwise orders, examinations conducted of a person under this rule by all parties of record must not, in total, exceed 3 hours in duration.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Application of examination for discovery rules
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Rule 7-2 (12), (16), (18), (22) and (25) to (28) applies to an examination under this rule.

If the physical or mental condition of a person is in issue in an action, the court may order that the person submit to examination by a medical practitioner or other qualified person, and if the court makes an order under this subrule, the court may also make

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an order respecting any expenses connected with the examination, and
an order that the result of the examination be put in writing and that copies be made available to interested parties of record.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The court may order a further examination under this rule.
A person who is making an examination under this rule may ask any relevant question concerning the medical condition or history of the person being examined.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Order for inspection and preservation of property
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the court considers it necessary or expedient for the purpose of obtaining full information or evidence, it may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: order the production, inspection and preservation of any property, and
authorize

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: samples to be taken or observations to be made of the property, or
experiments to be conducted on or with the property.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: For the purpose of enabling an order under this rule to be carried out, the court may authorize a person to enter on any land or building.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Application to persons outside British Columbia
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Rule 7-2 (27) and (28) applies to examinations and inspections ordered under this rule.

In an action in which a response to civil claim has been filed, a party of record may, by service of a notice to admit in Form 26, request any party of record to admit, for the purposes of the action only, the truth of a fact or the authenticity of a document specified in the notice.

Unless the court otherwise orders, the truth of a fact or the authenticity of a document specified in a notice to admit is deemed to be admitted, for the purposes of the action only, unless, within 14 days after service of the notice to admit, the party receiving the notice to admit serves on the party serving the notice to admit a written statement that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: specifically denies the truth of the fact or the authenticity of the document,
sets out in detail the reasons why the party cannot make the admission, or

states that the refusal to admit the truth of the fact or the authenticity of the document is made on the grounds of privilege or irrelevancy or that the request is otherwise improper, and sets out in detail the reasons for the refusal.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Copy of document to be attached
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Unless the court otherwise orders or the demanding party and the responding party consent, a copy of a document specified in a notice to admit must be attached to the notice to admit when it is served.

If a responding party unreasonably denies or refuses to admit the truth of a fact or the authenticity of a document specified in a notice to admit, the court may order the party to pay the costs of proving the truth of the fact or the authenticity of the document and may award as a penalty additional costs, or deprive a party of costs, as the court considers appropriate.
A party is not entitled to withdraw

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an admission made in response to a notice to admit,
a deemed admission under subrule (2), or
an admission made in a pleading, petition or response to petition

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: except by consent or with leave of the court.
An application for judgment or any other application may be made to the court using as evidence

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: admissions of the truth of a fact or the authenticity of a document made

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: in an affidavit or pleading filed by a party,
in an examination for discovery of a party or a person examined for discovery on behalf of a party, or
in response to a notice to admit, or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: admissions of the truth of a fact or the authenticity of a document deemed to be made under subrule (2)

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: and the court, without waiting for the determination of any other question between the parties, may make any order it considers will further the object of these Supreme Court Civil Rules.

By consent of the parties of record or by order of the court, a person may be examined on oath before or during trial in order that the record of the examination may be available to be tendered as evidence at the trial.
An examination under subrule (1) may be conducted before an official reporter or any other person as the court may direct.
In determining whether to exercise its discretion to order an examination under subrule (1), the court must take into account

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the convenience of the person sought to be examined,
the possibility that the person may be unavailable to testify at the trial by reason of death, infirmity, sickness or absence,
the possibility that the person will be beyond the jurisdiction of the court at the time of the trial,
the possibility and desirability of having the person testify at trial by video conferencing or other electronic means, and
the expense of bringing the person to the trial.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: In an order under subrule (1), the court may impose limits on the duration of the direct examination or cross examination of a person under this rule.

If the court makes an order under subrule (1) entitling a party to examine a person under this rule, the party may, by serving on the person to be examined a subpoena in Form 25, require the person to bring to the examination,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the person to be examined is not a party of record or a representative of a party of record, any document in the person's possession or control relating to the matters in question in the action, and
any physical object in the person's possession or control that the examining party contemplates tendering at the trial as an exhibit.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A subpoena referred to in subrule (5)

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: need not identify any document referred to in subrule (5) (a), and
must identify any object referred to in subrule (5) (b).

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Unless the court otherwise orders or the parties to the examination consent, an examination under this rule must take place at a location within 30 kilometres of the registry that is nearest to the place where the person to be examined resides.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Application of rule outside British Columbia
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: So far as is practicable, this rule applies to the examination of a person residing outside British Columbia, and the court may order the examination of a person in the place and the manner the court considers appropriate.

If the person whose examination is ordered under subrule (8) is willing to testify, the order under subrule (8) must be in Form 27 and the instructions to the examiner appointed in the order must be in Form 28.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If person not willing to testify
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the person whose examination is ordered under subrule (8) is unwilling to testify, or if for any other reason the assistance of a foreign court is necessary, the order under subrule (8) must be in Form 29 and the letter of request referred to in the order must be in Form 30.

If an order referred to in subrule (10) is made, the letter of request must be sent by the party obtaining the order to the Under Secretary of State for External Affairs of Canada (or, if the evidence is to be taken in Canada, to the Deputy Attorney General for the Province of British Columbia), and must have attached to it

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: any interrogatories to be put to the witness,
a list of the names, addresses and telephone numbers of the lawyers or agents of the parties, both in British Columbia and in the other jurisdiction, and
a copy of the letter of request and any interrogatories

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: translated into the appropriate official language of the jurisdiction where the examination is to take place, and
bearing the certificate of the translator that it is a true translation and giving the translator's full name and address.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The lawyer for the party obtaining the order referred to in subrule (10) must file with the Under Secretary of State for External Affairs of Canada (or the Deputy Attorney General for the Province of British Columbia, as the case may be) the lawyer's undertaking to be personally responsible for all the charges and expenses incurred by the Under Secretary (or the Deputy Attorney General, as the case may be) in respect of the letter of request and to pay those charges and expenses on receiving notification of the amount.

The examining party must give notice of an examination under this rule by serving copies of the subpoena referred to in subrule (5) on all parties of record at least 7 days before the date appointed for the examination.
The examining party must conduct a direct examination of the witness and the witness is subject to cross-examination and re-examination.
If an objection is made to a question put to a witness in an examination under this rule,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the question and the objection must be taken down by the official reporter,
the validity of the objection may, on application, be decided by the court, and
the court may, on an application referred to in paragraph (b), order the witness to submit to further examination.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Unless otherwise ordered, an examination under this rule must be recorded by the person authorized under subrule (2) to conduct the examination

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the form of questions and answers, or
on a video recording.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a person alleges that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: circumstances exist that entitle the person to receive an estate or interest in property on the happening of a future event, and
the right or claim to that estate or interest cannot be brought to trial or hearing by the person before the happening of the event,

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: the person may apply by petition or by requisition in Form 31 for an order to preserve, by examination under this rule, any testimony that may be material for establishing the right or claim.

bcl:rule.bcl:text: How to Bring and Respond to Applications

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: In this rule, application respondent means a person who files an application response under subrule (9).
To apply for an order from the court other than at trial or at the hearing of a petition, a party must do the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of an application for an order by consent, apply in accordance with

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: this rule, or
Rule 8-3;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of an application of which notice need not be given, apply in accordance with

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: this rule, or
Rule 8-4;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of an urgent application, apply in accordance with Rule 8-5;
in the case of an application referred to in Rule 8-6 that may be made by written submissions, apply in accordance with the directions of the case planning conference judge referred to in Rule 8-6;
in the case of an application for which a procedure is provided for by these Supreme Court Civil Rules, apply in accordance with that procedure;
in the case of any other application, apply in accordance with this rule.

bcl:lefttext.in:em: [The ability of a party to a fast track action to bring an application under this Part may be limited — see Rule 15-1 (7) to (9).]

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A party wishing to apply under this rule must file

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a notice of application, and
the original of every affidavit, and of every other document, that

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: is to be referred to by the applicant at the hearing, and
has not already been filed in the proceeding.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A notice of application must be in Form 32 and must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: set out the orders sought or attach a draft of the order sought,
briefly summarize the factual basis for the application,
set out the rule, enactment or other jurisdictional authority relied on for the orders sought and any other legal arguments on which the orders sought should be granted,
list the affidavits and other documents on which the applicant intends to rely at the hearing of the application,
set out the applicant's estimate of the time the application will take for hearing,
subject to subrules (5) and (6), set out the date and time of the hearing of the application,
set out the place for the hearing of the application in accordance with Rule 8-2, and
provide the data collection information required in the appendix to the form,

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: and the notice of application, other than any draft order attached to it under paragraph (a), must not exceed 10 pages in length.

Subject to subrule (6), the hearing of an application must be set for 9:45 a.m. on a date on which the court hears applications or at such other time or date as has been fixed by the court or a registrar.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Date and time if hearing time more than 2 hours
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the applicant's estimate referred to in subrule (4) (e) is more than 2 hours, the date and time of hearing must be fixed by a registrar.
The applicant must serve the following, in accordance with subrule (8), on each of the parties of record and on every other person, other than a party, who may be affected by the orders sought:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a copy of the filed notice of application;
a copy of each of the filed affidavits and documents, referred to in the notice of application under subrule (4) (d), that has not already been served on that person;
if the application is brought under Rule 9-7, any notice that the applicant is required to give under Rule 9-7 (9).

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The documents referred to in subrule (7) of this rule must be served,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: subject to paragraph (b) of this subrule, at least 8 business days before the date set for the hearing of the application, or
in the case of an application under Rule 9-7, at least 12 business days before the date set for the hearing of the application.

bcl:subrule.bcl:hnote: [am. B.C. Reg. 241/2010, Sch. A, s. 1 (c) and (d).]

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A person who is served with documents referred to in subrule (7) of this rule and who wishes to respond to the notice of application (in this subrule called the "responding person") must do the following within 5 business days after service or, in the case of an application under Rule 9-7, within 8 business days after service:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: file an application response;
file the original of every affidavit, and of every other document, that

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: is to be referred to by the responding person at the hearing, and
has not already been filed in the proceeding;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: serve on the applicant 2 copies of the following, and on every other party of record one copy of the following:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a copy of the filed application response;
a copy of each of the filed affidavits and documents, referred to in the application response under subrule (10) (b) (ii), that has not already been served on that person;
if the application is brought under Rule 9-7, any notice that the application respondent is required to give under Rule 9-7 (9).

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: An application response must be in Form 33, must not exceed 10 pages in length and must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: indicate, for each order sought on the application, whether the application respondent consents to, opposes or takes no position on the order, and
if the application respondent wishes to oppose any of the relief sought in the application,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: briefly summarize the factual and legal bases on which the orders sought should not be granted,
list the affidavits and other documents to which the application respondent intends to refer at the hearing of the application, and
set out the application respondent's estimate of the time the application will take for hearing.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: An application respondent who has not yet provided an address for service in the proceeding must include an address for service in any application response filed under subrule (9), and Rule 4-1 applies.
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 241/2010, Sch. A, s. 1 (g).]

An applicant who wishes to respond to any document served under subrule (9) must file and serve on each application respondent any responding affidavits no later than 4 p.m. on the business day that is one full business day before the date set for the hearing.
Unless all parties of record consent or the court otherwise orders, a party must not serve any affidavits additional to those served under subrules (7), (9) and (13).
Subject to subrule (18), the applicant must provide to the registry where the hearing is to take place an application record as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the application record must be in a ring binder or in some other form of secure binding;
the application record must contain, in consecutively numbered pages, or separated by tabs, the following documents in the following order:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a title page bearing the style of proceeding and the names of the lawyers, if any, for the applicant and the application respondents;
an index;
a copy of the filed notice of application;
a copy of each filed application response;
a copy of every filed affidavit and pleading, and of every other document other than a written argument, that is to be relied on at the hearing;
if the application is brought under Rule 9-7, a copy of each filed pleading;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the application record may contain

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a draft of the proposed order,
subject to subrule (16), a written argument,
a list of authorities and
a draft bill of costs;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the application record must not contain

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: affidavits of service,
copies of authorities, including case law, legislation, legal articles or excerpts from text books, or
any other documents unless they are included with the consent of all the parties of record;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the application record must be provided to the registry

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: no earlier than 9 a.m. on the business day that is three full business days before the date set for the hearing and no later than 4 p.m. on the business day that is one full business day before the date set for the hearing, or
if an earlier date is fixed by a registrar, on or before that date.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Unless an application is estimated to take more than 2 hours, no party to the application may file or submit to the court a written argument in relation to the application other than that included in the party's notice of application or application response.

The applicant must serve a copy of the application record index on each application respondent no later than 4 p.m. on the business day that is one full business day before the date set for the hearing.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If application respondent's application is to be heard at the hearing
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If an application respondent intends to set an application for hearing at the same time as the applicant's application, those parties must, so far as is possible, prepare and provide to the registry where the hearing is to take place a joint application record and agree to a date for the hearing of both applications.
Unless the court otherwise orders, the applicant must retrieve the application record

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: at the conclusion of the hearing, or
if the hearing of the application is adjourned to a date later than the following business day, after the hearing is adjourned.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Application record to be returned to the registry
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the application record has been retrieved by the applicant under subrule (19) (b), the applicant must return the application record to the registry between 9:00 a.m. and 4 p.m. on the business day that is one full business day before the new date set for the hearing of the application.

If any additional affidavits are filed and served under subrule (14) and are not included in the application record, the applicant must provide to the registry an amended application record containing those affidavits.
To reset an application that has been adjourned without a date being set for it to be heard ("adjourned generally"), the applicant must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: file a requisition in Form 17 setting out the date and time of the hearing, and
serve a copy of the filed requisition on the application respondents at least 2 business days before the date set for the hearing.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Application respondent may apply for directions
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If, after an application has been adjourned generally, the applicant does not reset the application for hearing within a reasonable time after an application respondent has requested the applicant to do so, an application respondent may apply, by requisition in Form 17 on 2 business days' notice, for directions.
An application may be heard at

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the place ordered by a registrar under subrule (4),
if an order is not made under subrule (4), the place on which all parties of record have agreed, or
if paragraphs (a) and (b) do not apply, a place at which the court normally sits in the judicial district in which the proceeding is being conducted.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If there is more than one place within the judicial district referred to in subrule (1) (c) at which the court normally sits, the applicant may name, as the place for hearing, any of those places.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If place of hearing is a place other than that at which the proceeding is being conducted
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If, under subrule (2), the applicant names as the place for hearing a place that is different than the place at which the proceeding is being conducted, the court may, if the court considers that it was unreasonable to have that named place as the place of hearing, make a special order as to costs and may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: order that the application be heard at some other place,
dismiss the application, or
hear the application.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Place of hearing of application with leave of registrar
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a registrar is satisfied that, due to urgency or the convenience of the parties, an application should be heard at a place outside the judicial district in which the proceeding is being conducted, the registrar may, without notice, grant leave for the applicant to do either or both of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: file the notice of application in some other judicial district;
name as the place of hearing a place in that other judicial district.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Notice of application must be endorsed to reflect grant of leave
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a registrar grants leave under subrule (4), he or she must endorse the notice of application accordingly.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If place of hearing is a place chosen with leave of registrar
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If, in respect of an application for which leave was granted under subrule (4), the court at the hearing of the application considers that the application should not be heard at that place, the court may make a special order as to costs and may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: order that the application be heard at some other place,
dismiss the application, or
hear the application.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 119/2010, Sch. A, s. 19.]
Subject to subrule (2), an application for an order by consent may be made by filing

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a requisition in Form 31,
a draft of the proposed order in Form 34,
evidence, in accordance with Rule 13-1 (10), that the application is consented to, and
any consent or comments of the Public Guardian and Trustee required under section 40 of the Infants Act.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: On being satisfied that an application referred to in subrule (1) of this rule is consented to and that the materials appropriate for the application have been filed in accordance with subrule (1), a registrar may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: refer the application to a judge or, if the order sought is within the jurisdiction of a master, to a judge or master, or
if the registrar is satisfied that

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: none of the parties applying for or consenting to the order is under a legal disability, or
if a party is under a legal disability, section 40 (7) of the Infants Act applies,

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: enter the order or proceed under paragraph (a) of this subrule.
If an application is referred by a registrar to a judge or master under subrule (2), the judge or master may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: make the order, or
give directions respecting the application.

bcl:rule.bcl:text: Applications of Which Notice Is Not Required

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Application of which notice is not required
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: An application of which notice is not required may be made by filing

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a requisition in Form 31,
a draft of the proposed order in Form 35, and
affidavit or other evidence in support of the application.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 119/2010, Sch. A, s. 20 (b).]

bcl:centertext.in:strong: When Applications May Be Heard on Short Notice

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Without limiting subrule (6), in case of urgency, a person wishing to bring an application (in this subrule and in subrules (2) to (5) called the "main application") on less notice than would normally be required may make an application (in this subrule and in subrules (2) to (4) called the "short notice application") for an order that the main application may be brought on short notice.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How to make a short notice application
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A short notice application may be made by requisition in Form 17.1, without notice, and in a summary way.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Normal time and notice rules do not apply
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The time limits and notice requirements provided in these Supreme Court Civil Rules do not apply to a short notice application.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Powers of court on short notice application
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: On a short notice application, the court or a registrar may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: order that the main application be heard on short notice,
fix the date and time for the main application to be heard,
fix the date and time before which service of documents applicable to the main application must be made, and
give any other directions that the court or registrar considers will further the object of these Supreme Court Civil Rules.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If an order is made under subrule (4) that the main application be heard on short notice, the time limits and notice requirements provided in these Supreme Court Civil Rules do not apply to the main application.

bcl:centertext.in:strong: When Applications May Be Heard without Any Notice

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The court may make an order without notice in the case of urgency.

Promptly after an order is made without notice by reason of urgency, the party who obtained the order must serve a copy of the entered order and the documents filed in support on each person who is affected by the order.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Setting aside orders made without notice
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: On the application of a person affected by an order made without notice under subrule (6), the court may change or set aside the order.
If an order is made at a case planning conference that an application may be made by written submissions,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the case planning conference judge or master must give directions respecting the application, including directions respecting

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the documents to be filed in support of the application, and
the persons on whom and the dates by which the documents referred to in subparagraph (i) and any other documents the judge or master may identify must be served, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the application may be made in the manner provided for in those directions.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: In this rule, offer to settle means

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an offer to settle made and delivered before July 2, 2008 under Rule 37 of the former Supreme Court Rules, as that rule read on the date of the offer to settle, and in relation to which no order was made under that rule,

an offer of settlement made and delivered before July 2, 2008 under Rule 37A of the former Supreme Court Rules, as that rule read on the date of the offer of settlement, and in relation to which no order was made under that rule, or
an offer to settle made after July 1, 2008 under Rule 37B of the former Supreme Court Rules, as that rule read on the date of the offer to settle, or made under this rule, that

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: is made in writing by a party to a proceeding,
has been served on all parties of record, and

contains the following sentence: "The ............[party(ies)]............, ............[name(s) of party(ies)]............, reserve(s) the right to bring this offer to the attention of the court for consideration in relation to costs after the court has pronounced judgment on all other issues in this proceeding."

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The fact that an offer to settle has been made must not be disclosed to the court or jury, or set out in any document used in the proceeding, until all issues in the proceeding, other than costs, have been determined.
An offer to settle is not an admission.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Offer may be considered in relation to costs
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The court may consider an offer to settle when exercising the court's discretion in relation to costs.
In a proceeding in which an offer to settle has been made, the court may do one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: deprive a party of any or all of the costs, including any or all of the disbursements, to which the party would otherwise be entitled in respect of all or some of the steps taken in the proceeding after the date of delivery or service of the offer to settle;
award double costs of all or some of the steps taken in the proceeding after the date of delivery or service of the offer to settle;

award to a party, in respect of all or some of the steps taken in the proceeding after the date of delivery or service of the offer to settle, costs to which the party would have been entitled had the offer not been made;

if the offer was made by a defendant and the judgment awarded to the plaintiff was no greater than the amount of the offer to settle, award to the defendant the defendant's costs in respect of all or some of the steps taken in the proceeding after the date of delivery or service of the offer to settle.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: In making an order under subrule (5), the court may consider the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: whether the offer to settle was one that ought reasonably to have been accepted, either on the date that the offer to settle was delivered or served or on any later date;
the relationship between the terms of settlement offered and the final judgment of the court;
the relative financial circumstances of the parties;
any other factor the court considers appropriate.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Costs for settlement in cases within small claims jurisdiction
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A plaintiff who accepts an offer to settle for a sum within the jurisdiction of the Provincial Court under the Small Claims Act is not entitled to costs, other than disbursements, unless the court finds that there was sufficient reason for bringing the proceeding in the Supreme Court and so orders.
An offer to settle does not expire by reason that a counter offer is made.

If, at any stage of an action, the parties of record jointly request a settlement conference by filing a requisition in Form 17 or a judge or master directs that the parties attend a settlement conference, the parties must attend before a judge or master who must, in private and without hearing witnesses, explore all possibilities of settlement of the issues that are outstanding.
Proceedings at a settlement conference must be recorded, but no part of that recording may be made available to or used by any person without court order.
A judge who has presided at a settlement conference must not preside at the trial, unless all parties consent.
The parties to a proceeding may concur in stating a question of law or fact, or partly of law and partly of fact, in the form of a special case for the opinion of the court.

The court may order a question or issue arising in a proceeding, whether of fact or law or partly of fact and partly of law, and whether raised by the pleadings or otherwise, to be stated in the form of a special case.
A special case must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: be divided into paragraphs numbered consecutively,
state concisely such facts and set out or refer to such documents as may be necessary to enable the court to decide the questions stated, and
be signed by the parties or their lawyers.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: On the hearing of a special case, the court and the parties may refer to any document mentioned in the special case, and the court may draw from the stated facts and documents any inference, whether of fact or law, that might have been drawn from them if proved at a trial or hearing.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Order after hearing of special case
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: With the consent of the parties, on any question in a special case being answered, the court may grant specific relief or order judgment to be entered.

bcl:rule.bcl:text: Proceedings on a Point of Law

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Point of law may be set down for hearing
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A point of law arising from the pleadings in an action may, by consent of the parties or by order of the court, be set down by requisition in Form 17 for hearing and disposed of at any time before the trial.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Court may dispose of whole action
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If, in the opinion of the court, the decision on the point of law substantially disposes of the whole action or of any distinct claim, ground of defence, set-off or counterclaim, the court may dismiss the action or make any order it considers will further the object of these Supreme Court Civil Rules.
At any stage of a proceeding, the court may order to be struck out or amended the whole or any part of a pleading, petition or other document on the ground that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: it discloses no reasonable claim or defence, as the case may be,
it is unnecessary, scandalous, frivolous or vexatious,
it may prejudice, embarrass or delay the fair trial or hearing of the proceeding, or
it is otherwise an abuse of the process of the court,

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: and the court may pronounce judgment or order the proceeding to be stayed or dismissed and may order the costs of the application to be paid as special costs.
No evidence is admissible on an application under subrule (1) (a).
If, on the filing of a document, a registrar considers that the whole or any part of the document could be the subject of an order under subrule (1),

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the registrar may, despite any other provision of these Supreme Court Civil Rules,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: retain the document and all filed copies of it, and
refer the document to the court, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the court may, after a summary hearing, make an order under subrule (1).

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the court makes an order referred to in subrule (3) (b),

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the registrar must give notification of the order, in the manner directed by the court, to the person who filed the document,
the person who filed the document may, within 7 days after being notified, apply to the court, and
the court may confirm, vary or rescind the order.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: In this rule:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: answering party, in relation to a claiming party's originating pleading, means a person who serves, on the claiming party, a responding pleading that relates to a claim made in the originating pleading;
claiming party means a party who filed an originating pleading.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: In an action, a person who files an originating pleading in which a claim is made against a person may, after the person against whom the claim is made serves a responding pleading on the claiming party, apply under this rule for judgment against the answering party on all or part of the claim.
An answering party may respond to an application for judgment under subrule (2) as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the answering party may allege that the claiming party's originating pleading does not raise a cause of action against the answering party;

if the answering party wishes to make any other response to the application, the answering party may not rest on the mere allegations or denials in his or her pleadings but must set out, in affidavit material or other evidence, specific facts showing that there is a genuine issue for trial.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: In an action, an answering party may, after serving a responding pleading on a claiming party, apply under this rule for judgment dismissing all or part of a claim in the claiming party's originating pleading.
On hearing an application under subrule (2) or (4), the court,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if satisfied that there is no genuine issue for trial with respect to a claim or defence, must pronounce judgment or dismiss the claim accordingly,

if satisfied that the only genuine issue is the amount to which the claiming party is entitled, may order a trial of that issue or pronounce judgment with a reference or an accounting to determine the amount,
if satisfied that the only genuine issue is a question of law, may determine the question and pronounce judgment accordingly, and
may make any other order it considers will further the object of these Supreme Court Civil Rules.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If, under this rule, a claiming party obtains judgment against a person on a claim made against that person in the originating pleading, the judgment is without prejudice to the right of the claiming party to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: proceed with the action in respect of any other claim made, in the originating pleading, against the person against whom the judgment was obtained, and
proceed with the action against any other person against whom a claim is made in the originating pleading.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Subject to subrule (8), if the party applying under subrule (2) or (4) obtains no relief on the application, the court may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: fix the costs of the party responding to the application, and
fix the period within which those costs must be paid.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Court may decline to fix costs
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The court may decline to fix and order costs under subrule (7) if the court is satisfied that the application under subrule (2) or (4), although unsuccessful, was nevertheless reasonable.
If it appears to the court that a party to an application under subrule (2) or (4) has acted in bad faith or primarily for the purpose of delay, the court may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: fix the costs of the application as special costs, and
fix the period within which those costs must be paid.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: In this rule, summary trial application means an application referred to in subrule (2).
A party may apply to the court for judgment under this rule, either on an issue or generally, in any of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an action in which a response to civil claim has been filed;
a proceeding that has been transferred to the trial list under Rule 22-1 (7) (d);
a third party proceeding in which a response to third party notice has been filed;
an action by way of counterclaim in which a response to counterclaim has been filed.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A summary trial application must be heard at least 42 days before the scheduled trial date.
Unless the court otherwise orders, a summary trial application must be set for hearing in accordance with Rule 8-1.
Unless the court otherwise orders, on a summary trial application, the applicant and each other party of record may tender evidence by any or all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: affidavit;
an answer, or part of an answer, to interrogatories;
any part of the evidence taken on an examination for discovery;
an admission under Rule 7-7;
a report setting out the opinion of an expert, if

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the report conforms with Rule 11-6 (1), or
the court orders that the report is admissible even though it does not conform with Rule 11-6 (1).

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Rule 12-5 (46), (49), (50), (51), (56) to (58) applies to subrule (5) of this rule.
Rule 11-6 (2) applies to a summary trial application.
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 207/2020, s. 1.]
A party who applies for judgment under subrule (2)

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must serve, with the notice of application and the other documents referred to in Rule 8-1 (3), every expert report, not already filed, on which the party will rely in support of the application, and
must not serve any further affidavits, expert reports or notices except

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: to tender evidence that would, at a trial, be admitted as rebuttal evidence,
to respond to a notice of application filed and served by another party of record, or
with leave of the court.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Notice of evidence to be used on application
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a party intends, on a summary trial application, to rely on

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: evidence taken on an examination for discovery,
answers to interrogatories, or
admissions,

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: the party must give notice of that fact in accordance with subrule (10).
Notice under subrule (9) must be given

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by an applicant, in accordance with Rule 8-1 (7) and (8), and
by a party who is not an applicant, in accordance with Rule 8-1 (9).

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: On an application heard before or at the same time as the hearing of a summary trial application, the court may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: adjourn the summary trial application, or
dismiss the summary trial application on the ground that

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the issues raised by the summary trial application are not suitable for disposition under this rule, or
the summary trial application will not assist the efficient resolution of the proceeding.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: On or before the hearing of a summary trial application, the court may order that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a party file and serve, within a fixed time, any of the following on which the party intends to rely in support of the application:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: an affidavit;
a notice referred to in subrule (9),

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the person who swore or affirmed an affidavit, or an expert whose report is relied on, attend for cross-examination, either before the court or before another person as the court directs,
cross-examinations on affidavits be completed within a fixed time,
no further evidence be tendered on the application after a fixed time, or
a party file and serve a brief, with such contents as the court may order, within a fixed time.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Ancillary or preliminary orders may be made at or before application
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: An order under subrule (11) or (12) may be made by a judge or by a master, and may be made before or at the same time as a summary trial application.
A judge who makes an order under subrule (11) or (12) in relation to a summary trial application is not seized of the summary trial application unless the judge otherwise orders.
On the hearing of a summary trial application, the court may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: grant judgment in favour of any party, either on an issue or generally, unless

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the court is unable, on the whole of the evidence before the court on the application, to find the facts necessary to decide the issues of fact or law, or
the court is of the opinion that it would be unjust to decide the issues on the application,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: impose terms respecting enforcement of the judgment, including a stay of execution, and
award costs.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the court does not grant judgment under subrule (15), the applicant may not apply again under subrule (2) without leave of the court.
If the court is unable to grant judgment under subrule (15) and considers that the proceeding ought to be expedited, the court may order the trial of a proceeding generally or on an issue and may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: order that the parties attend a case planning conference,
make any order that may be made under Rule 5-3 (1), or
make any other order the court considers will further the object of these Supreme Court Civil Rules.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Right to vary or set aside order
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A court may, before or at trial, vary or set aside an order made under subrules (12) and (17) of this rule.
A party may apply to the court for judgment under subrule (2) even though a party may have filed a notice under Rule 12-6 (3) requiring that the trial of the action be heard with a jury.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Discontinuance before action set for trial
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: At any time before a notice of trial is filed in an action, a plaintiff may discontinue it in whole or in part against a defendant by filing a notice of discontinuance in Form 36 and serving a filed copy of the notice of discontinuance on all parties of record.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Discontinuance after action set for trial
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: After a notice of trial is filed in an action, a plaintiff may discontinue the action in whole or in part against a defendant with the consent of all parties of record or by leave of the court.

A defendant may withdraw his or her response to civil claim or any part of it with respect to any plaintiff at any time by filing a notice of withdrawal in Form 37 and serving a filed copy of the notice of withdrawal on all parties of record.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Costs and default procedure on discontinuance or withdrawal
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Subject to subrule (2), a person wholly discontinuing an action against a party or wholly withdrawing his or her response to civil claim filed in response to a notice of civil claim of a party must pay the costs of that party to the date of service of the notice of discontinuance or the notice of withdrawal, as the case may be, and if a plaintiff who is liable for costs under this subrule subsequently brings a proceeding for the same or substantially the same claim before paying those costs, the court may order the proceeding to be stayed until the costs are paid.

If a plaintiff discontinues the whole or any part of an action in which a person has been joined as a third party, the third party, if the discontinuance disposes of the claim against the third party, is entitled to costs and may apply to the court for a direction as to who should pay them.
A plaintiff's right to recover costs from a defendant under subrule (4) does not preclude the plaintiff recovering other costs properly incurred.
If a defendant wholly or partly withdraws his or her response under this rule, the plaintiff may proceed under Rule 3-8 as if the defendant had served no response or only a partial response.
Unless the court otherwise orders, the discontinuance of an action in whole or in part is not a defence to a subsequent proceeding for the same or substantially the same cause of action.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Application to counterclaim, third party proceeding and petition.
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: This rule applies to a counterclaim, a third party proceeding and a petition.
